evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew resists defeaters by accounting for all available evidence and ruling out alternative causes such as equipment failure or external interference in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary data.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common defeaters, supported by consistent evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary records.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary dataset, reflecting typical operational variances.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the historical dynamic understanding preliminary phase.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP despite crew communication indicates coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or mechanical failure caused the event instead.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows crew communication and coordination during pushback, including a trainee stopping and instructor taking over, yet the aircraft passed the TRP and hit a barrier, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively.

assumptions: The described interactions and actions reflect communication and coordination breakdowns as key features.
No other dominant causes (e.g., mechanical failure) override the communication breakdown explanation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination with no miscommunication or failure to share critical information, or if environmental/marking deficiencies were the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and operators, decisions to stop and resume pushback, and failure to stop at the designated point, indicating miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether environmental or marking deficiencies contributed significantly to the incident.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary data.

assumptions: The historical data referenced includes the event described in H4 as part of the preliminary dynamic data for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
The description of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier constitutes documentation of the procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the aircraft movement beyond the TRP was due to environmental factors such as inadequate or unclear ground markings, or if mechanical control failure was documented as the cause, this would change the assessment.
If communication breakdown evidence indicated the deviation was due to coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the deviation was due to procedural error or environmental/marking deficiency; no explicit documentation of the deviation beyond the event description.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical dynamic preliminary dataset, reflecting typical operational variances.

defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would favor mechanical control failure over procedural deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

Discriminator disc:R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE favors environmental deficiency over mechanical failure. Disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY favors procedural deviation, but the direct evidence of marking inadequacy supports environmental deficiency more strongly. Communication breakdown discriminators are neutral.

node.statement: Relevant environmental information was accessible to the flight crew during the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and awareness by the flight crew and tug operators, and the aircraft passed the TRP marking, indicating relevant environmental information was accessible, contradicting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the flight crew directly perceived the environmental markings despite communication.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H3 directly describe crew members physically present and accessible to each other during the event, supporting the claim and favoring communication breakdown over mechanical failure.

node.statement: Crew members were alert and capable of engaging in communication and coordination

defeaters: If evidence showed that the crew were fully alert and no miscommunication occurred leading to the incident, or if the aircraft movement beyond TRP was due to mechanical failure rather than coordination failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows active communication and coordination among crew members, but H4 shows the aircraft moved beyond the stop point causing a collision, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown. This supports R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN over procedural deviation as per discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.

assumptions: The historical data referenced includes the event described in H4 as part of the preliminary dynamic data for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25.
The description of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast barrier constitutes documentation of the procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the aircraft movement beyond the TRP was due to environmental factors such as inadequate or unclear ground markings, or if mechanical control failure was documented as the cause, this would change the assessment.

availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution by describing the aircraft moving beyond the designated Tug release point and hitting the blast barrier, supporting the claim that the deviation is documented and available in the historical data.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the deviation was due to procedural error or environmental/marking deficiency; no explicit documentation of the deviation beyond the event description.

assumptions: The historical records are accurate and complete regarding crew communication and actions.

defeaters: If evidence showed communication failures or coordination breakdowns causing the deviation, or environmental/technical factors explaining the event, this would change the assessment.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H4) shows clear procedural actions and communication during pushback, with the instructor correcting the trainee and the aircraft passing the TRP, supporting robust identification of procedural deviation and distinguishing it from communication breakdown.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication failure or environmental/technical causes; ambiguity remains if other factors contributed.

assumptions: No mechanical control failure was detected or reported in the evidence.
The described operator actions and environment reflect typical operational variances for this aircraft and dataset.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would favor mechanical control failure over procedural deviation.

fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity could arise if mechanical issues were later identified.

assumptions: The continued movement beyond TRP despite crew communication indicates coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident, or mechanical failure caused the event instead.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows crew communication and coordination during pushback, including a trainee stopping and instructor taking over, yet the aircraft passed the TRP and hit a barrier, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown supporting the claim.
availability.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviation or communication breakdown was primary cause

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or observed in the evidence provided.
defeaters: If evidence showed hardware faults or external interference causing the incident, the conclusion would change.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, with no indication of mechanical or equipment failure, supporting communication breakdown as cause and ruling out mechanical failure.

assumptions: The described interactions and actions reflect communication and coordination breakdowns as key features.
No other dominant causes (e.g., mechanical failure) override the communication breakdown explanation.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination with no miscommunication or failure to share critical information, or if environmental/marking deficiencies were the primary cause.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows communication among crew and operators, decisions to stop and resume pushback, and failure to stop at the designated point, indicating miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively, supporting the claim.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are considered part of environmental/marking conditions

defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP ground markings and hit a barrier, indicating a marking or environmental deficiency rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure. Discriminator disc:R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY|R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE favors environmental deficiency over mechanical failure. Disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY favors procedural deviation, but the direct evidence of marking inadequacy supports environmental deficiency more strongly.
